Award.AwardTitle: Postdoctoral Fellowship: Concepts of Information in Neuroscience

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project will provide a conceptual analysis of the notion of information for the purposes of contributing to foundational research in neuroscience. The project is both timely and important since explanation within contemporary neuroscience relies heavily on various concepts of information that are seldom if ever explicitly defined. Neuroscientists have often stressed the need for more foundational thinking in their field but seldom have the chance to step back and address these issues. An empirically-informed philosopher of science will work collaboratively with colleagues in neuroscience to make significant contributions to the field by addressing a highly specific concern about the different uses made of concepts of information in particular kinds of explanation from neurophysiology of receptor cells to fMRI studies about sensory or motor systems.

The results of this research will benefit society by facilitating public understanding of neuroscience. There is a large interest among the public about how our brains work, as made evident by the stream of popular science books, news articles, and TV documentaries on this topic. The appeal to information is standard in these offerings to the public, but mired in the same confusions that exist in the scientific literature. Clarifying and revising the information concepts as used in neuroscience should therefore also have a significant impact on its public understanding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant resulted in two major projects and a conference. 
The first of those projects investigates the assumptions needed to apply the mathematical theory of information to biological phenomena within a single organism. A comparison is made between the conceptual difficulties encountered when applying information theory to biological phenomena and those encountered when information theory is applied to human artifacts. The most salient result of this comparison is that there is a wider class of possible mistakes in the biological case. Moreover, these mistakes can be prevented by attending more carefully than has been done thus far to the empirical interpretation of certain mathematical assumptions upon which the theoretical apparatus relies. These assumptions are discussed in the context of a well known case of the H1 neuron in the blowfly. This project has been written up as full-length research article and is currently under review at the journal Biology and Philosophy. 
The second project has to do with the articulation of a new concept of information that seems implicit in the models of cognitive neuroscience. Philosophers often suggest a simple contrast between correlational information and semantic information. Semantic information (or, at least one variety of semantic information) is the content carried by a physical signal, where the association between the signal and its content is established by means of a convention. Correlational information is simply the potential knowledge about the value of one variable, given that that variable is correlated with another. Neural signals are ubiquitously described as carrying information, but at least many low-level signals do not qualify as semantic. Nevertheless, scientific practice suggests that the  far more than mere correlation is required before some activity is described as carrying information. To make sense of this situation, a new concept of information is developed according to which semantic signals have non-semantic parts. To be part of a semantic signal is to carry a certain kind of information that is richer than mere correlational information, and yet more common than semantic information itself. An argument is presented that this third variety of information is at work in many areas of neuroscience. This project is described in a full-length manuscript which is currently in preparation. 
The grant also resulted in an international conference on concepts of information in the sciences. The conference, which was held in Manhattan at the CUNY’s graduate center, involved a series of talks on the many uses of information in the biological, psychological, and social sciences. The interdisciplinary conference, in addition to providing an excellent forum through which the Co-PI received feedback on his research, highlighted the many meanings of the claim that we live in the “information age.”
